item.title: Session 4: Homework 2
item.description: Climate change and temperature anomalies If we wanted to study climate change, we can find data on the Combined Land-Surface Air and Sea-Surface Water Temperature Anomalies in the Northern Hemisphere at NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies. The tabular data of temperature anomalies can be found here To define temperature anomalies you need to have a reference, or base, period which NASA clearly states that it is the period between 1951-1980.

item.title: US Yield Curve Inversion
item.description: Challenge 1: Yield Curve inversion Every so often, we hear warnings from commentators on the “inverted yield curve” and its predictive power with respect to recessions. An explainer what a inverted yield curve is can be found here. If you’d rather listen to something, here is a great podcast from NPR on yield curve indicators In addition, many articles and commentators think that, e.g., Yield curve inversion is viewed as a harbinger of recession.

item.title: Project 1: Lets play around with some Stocks!
item.description: Lets take a look at the NYSE #Downloading the data we need nyse <- read_csv(here::here("data","nyse.csv")) Lets see how the NYSE is made up #Grouping the companies in the NYSE by sector companies_per_sector <- nyse %>% group_by(sector) %>% summarise(count=count(sector)) %>% arrange(desc(count)) #Lets see what it looks like in a bar graph bar <- companies_per_sector %>% ggplot(aes(y=reorder(sector,count),x=count))+ geom_col()+ labs(y="",x="# of Companies",title="Companies in the NYSE")+ theme_economist_white() bar Now lets look at the Dow Jones Industrial Aveareg (DJIA) djia_url <- "https://en.
